p: The isolates from chicken were sensitive to erythromycin and gentamicin, but they were resistant to quinolones and tetracycline. The mutations in gyrA and tet(O) were confirmed by DNA sequencing. The tested NPs were active against both antibiotic-sensitive and antibiotic-resistant Campylobacter strains. Effective NPs can be exploited by the food processing industry and poultry farms to control foodborne pathogens. There is a need to understand the mode of action of these NPs before they are used in clinical settings.
